title: temperature change
text:
Introduction
So far, we have been describing heat transfer in terms of what happens to a given parcel of fluid. A transient model must instead describe what happens at a given point in the flow field.
The temperature of fluid at different points along a pipe is a result of multiple factors:

Heat exchange between the fluid and its surroundings. (The effect of the ambient conditions)
Movement through the pipe: If the fluid temperature is not uniform, we should observe areas of high and low temperature moving with the fluid.
Heat diffusion within the fluid: The temperature of the fluid should become more uniform over time, all else equal.
Maybe some effect from pressure change. It’s unclear how relevant this is and I don’t expect it to have a huge effect in pipes.

Our current model accounts for #1 and #4, but not #2 and #3. There is an implicit assumption that the parcels of fluid either side of the one we follow through a pipe had the same conditions leaving the emitter, and that these parcels of fluid have no effect on their neighbours.

title: 1  Ambient
text:
The fluid loses heat to the surroundings when it is above ambient temperature and absorbs heat when below.
This is probably the easiest part to model. At each point, \frac{\delta T}{\delta t}_{a} will be proportional somehow to the difference in temperature between the fluid and ambient. The temperature difference and the u value of the pipe wall determine the rate of energy transfer, and the specific heat at constant pressure will determine how that translates into temperature change.


Show the code
using Plots

plot(x -> 1 / ℯ^x,
    0,
    2π,
    label="temperature",
    xlabel="time"
)





Figure 1.1: Temperature falling over time

title: 2  Movement
text:
Properties that change at an emitter will take time to propagate, moving with the fluid.


Show the code
using Plots

@gif for i ∈ 1:62
    plot(
        x -> 0.5 * sin(x - 0.1 * i),
        xlims=(0, 4π),
        ylims=(-1, 1),
        label="temperature",
        xlabel="displacement",
    )
end

title: 3  Diffusion
text:
Even without flow or any heat exchange with the surroundings, the temperature distribution should become more uniform over time.


Show the code
using Plots

@gif for i ∈ 20:80
    plot(
        x -> 10 * sin(x) / i,
        xlims=(0, 4π),
        ylims=(-1, 1),
        label="temperature",
        xlabel="displacement",
    )
end
